ai-ud1.4:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
ai-ud1.4:1.3_0: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-ud1.4:1.4_0: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
ai-ud1.4:2.1_0: Then a certain brahmin of the whiny sort went up to the Buddha.
ai-ud1.4:2.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side.
ai-ud1.4:2.3_0: He went to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
ai-ud1.4:2.4_0: “Good Gotama, how is one a brahmin? What are the things that make one a brahmin?”
ai-ud1.4:3.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud1.4:4.1_0: “A brahmin who has barred out bad qualities,
ai-ud1.4:4.3_0: a complete knowledge master who has completed the spiritual journey—
ai-ud1.4:4.4_0: may rightly proclaim the brahmin doctrine,
ai-ud1.4:4.5_0: He may proclaim himself a brahmin.”
